abstract: With the economic crisis roiling Europe, fears have been growing among cultural observers that cash-strapped countries could sell cultural treasures to avert financial insolvency. In Spain these concerns were fanned after it emerged that Catalunya Caixa, a struggling savings bank that owns the Antoni Gaudi Barcelona masterpiece Casa Milà, could be forced to put that architectural jewel up for sale.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — With the economic crisis roiling Europe, fears have been growing among cultural observers that cash-strapped countries like Greece, Spain and Italy could sell cultural treasures to avert financial insolvency. In Spain these concerns were fanned in recent weeks after it emerged that Catalunya Caixa, a struggling savings bank that owns the Antoni Gaudi Barcelona masterpiece Casa Milà, could be forced to put that architectural jewel up for sale.
